benchmark_details.name: ICE-ID (Identity Resolution Benchmark)
benchmark_details.overview: ICE-ID is a novel benchmark dataset for historical identity resolution, comprising 220 years (1703â€“1920) of Icelandic census records. It captures name variations, demographic changes, and genealogical links, focusing on long-term person-entity matching in a real-world population.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To enable reproducible benchmarking of identity resolution approaches in longitudinal settings and stimulate cross-disciplinary research in data linkage and historical analytics.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Snapshot waves only; kinship signal sparsity; label noise in early records; modalities and unstructured data are not included.

data.source: Digitized Icelandic census records from varying years combined with auxiliary data.
data.size: 984,028 raw rows with 200,000 high-confidence cluster labels
data.annotation: Expert-curated cluster labels and normalization of names.

methodology.calculation: Metrics calculated using pairwise comparisons and clustering quality assessments based on thresholds.
methodology.interpretation: Scores are interpreted with respect to their roles in defining matching efficiency and clustering coherence.
methodology.baseline_results: F1 Score of 0.9613 on combined tasks with ML ensemble.
methodology.validation: Evaluated through temporal splits mirroring real archival workflows.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The dataset includes population demographic shifts over the analyzed period.
harm: Potential privacy breaches from individual linkage.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: There is a risk of exposing sensitive personal information through linked genealogical data.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: Open-access license for shared data and artifacts.
